title: Excel Functions and Charts Practice: Party Planning Dataset

steps.title: Basic Functions Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Working with SUM and COUNTA Functions

For this set of activities, you will need the 4-2 Party planning file.

This can be found in the FUNCTIONS & CHARTS section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

Create a New Worksheet

First, create a new sheet named 'Basic Functions' to store your results.

Exercise 1: Add Recipe Count Column

Let's go back to the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet now. You'll notice columns J, K, and L already contain Maximum, Minimum, and Total calculations. Let's add a new column to count recipe usage:

  1. In cell M1, add the header 'Recipe Count'.
  2. In cell M2, use the COUNTA function to count how many recipes use baking powder (first ingredient).
  3. Copy this formula down to calculate recipe counts for all ingredients (rows 2-22) using autofill (double clicking the little box at the bottom right of the selected cell).
  1. In your 'Basic Functions' sheet, paste the ingredient names (column A) and their recipe counts (column M).
    2. Important Note About Pasting Values

    Did your recipe count convert to 1s when you pasted the column into your other sheet? This is because it's copied the formula, and the formula can't find the cell it was looking for before. To paste the values of the result, press CTRL SHIFT V when pasting, or use this button when right clicking to paste.

Exercise 2: Create SUM Calculations

Let's go back to the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet now.

Now let's create the Total column calculations that are missing:

  1. In cell L1, add the header 'Total' if it's not already there.
  2. In cell L2, create a SUM formula to calculate the total amount of baking powder across all recipes.
  3. Copy this formula down to calculate totals for all ingredients (rows 2-22).
  4. Copy Column L and then paste it into Column C in your basic formulas sheet.
  5. If you haven't already, add headers to your basic formula sheet, so that at the top it says: A1='Ingredient', B1='Recipe Count', C1='Total Amount'
Your basic functions sheet should have data in columns B and C. The image above is just an example for the headers.

quiz.question: What is the difference between SUM and COUNTA functions?
options: SUM adds numbers together, COUNTA counts non-empty cells
SUM counts cells, COUNTA adds numbers

steps.title: Advanced Functions Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Using MAX and MIN Functions

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Advanced Functions'.

Exercise 1: Create MAX Functions

Let's add Maximum value calculations to the dataset:

  1. In cell J1, add the header 'Maximum' if it's not already there.
  2. In cell J2, create a MAX formula to find the highest amount of baking powder used in any single recipe.
  3. Copy this formula down to find the maximum amount for each ingredient (rows 2-22) using autofill (double clicking the square at the bottom right of the cell).
  4. Now filter to show only ingredients with high maximum values:
    • Select the entire data range (A1:M22)
    • Go to Data tab → Filter (this adds dropdown arrows to your headers)
    • Click the dropdown arrow in the Maximum column (column J)
    • Choose 'Number Filters' → 'Greater Than' → type '100' → OK
  5. Copy the filtered results to your 'Advanced Functions' sheet:
    • Select and copy the visible filtered rows from columns A and J (ingredient names and maximum values)
    • Paste into your 'Advanced Functions' sheet starting at A1
    • Add headers: A1='Ingredient', B1='Maximum Value'
Exercise 2: Create MIN Functions

Now let's add Minimum value calculations:

  1. Return to the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet and clear any filters (Data → Filter to toggle off).
  2. In cell K1, add the header 'Minimum' if it's not already there.
  3. In cell K2, create a MIN formula to find the smallest amount of baking powder.
  4. Copy this formula down to all ingredient rows (rows 2-22).
  5. In your 'Advanced Functions' sheet, add the minimum data:
    • Copy ingredient names from column A, rows 2-22 of the Recipe ingredients sheet
    • Paste into column C of your Advanced Functions sheet
    • Copy minimum values from column K, rows 2-22 of the Recipe ingredients sheet
    • Paste into column D of your Advanced Functions sheet
    • Add headers: C1='Ingredient', D1='Minimum Value'

quiz.question: If you want to find the largest value across multiple non-adjacent ranges, which formula structure would work?

steps.title: Chart Creation Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Visualising Recipe Data

Create a New Worksheet

Create a new sheet named 'Charts Practice'.

Exercise 1: Ingredient Usage Chart

Create a column chart showing how caster sugar is used across recipes:

  1. On the 'Recipe ingredients' sheet, select the range A1:I1 (headers) and A7:I7 (caster sugar row) while holding Ctrl.
  2. Go to the Insert tab at the top of the ribbon.
  3. Click 'Recommended Charts'.
  4. Select 'Column or Bar Chart' and choose '2-D Clustered Column'.
  5. Customise your chart:
    • Title: 'Caster Sugar Usage Across Recipes'
    • Add data labels by clicking the + button next to the chart
  6. Copy this chart to your 'Charts Practice' sheet.

steps.title: Recipe Analysis Practice
steps.content:
Practice: Inside One Cake Analysis

Navigate to the Inside One Cake Sheet

You'll find a sheet called 'Inside one cake' in your workbook. This sheet contains recipe data and instructions for a hands-on analysis activity.

Click on the 'Inside one cake' tab at the bottom of your Excel window to begin.

Getting Started

The 'Inside one cake' sheet contains:

  • Recipe data for different types of cakes and muffins
  • Conversion table to help convert measurements to grams
  • Step-by-step instructions for creating charts and analysis

Follow the instructions on the sheet to:

  1. Choose a recipe to analyse
  2. Convert measurements to grams using the conversion table
  3. Create a pie chart showing ingredient proportions
  4. Answer the reflection questions
Helpful Tips & Hints

Hint: Pick a recipe that interests you! All recipes will work for this activity.

Tip: Recipes with more ingredients (like chocolate cake) might give more interesting pie chart results.

Formula help: To convert using the table, use a formula like:

=Original_Amount * Conversion_Factor

Example: If you have 2 cups of flour, and 1 cup = 142g, then: =2*142

Common conversions to remember:

  • 1 cup = varies by ingredient (check the table!)
  • 1 tbsp = varies by ingredient
  • 1 tsp = varies by ingredient
  • 1 egg ≈ 50g

Chart creation steps:

  1. Select your ingredient names AND their gram amounts
  2. Insert → Charts → Recommended Charts → Pie Chart
  3. Choose the 2-D Pie option
  4. Add data labels to show percentages

Chart formatting tips:

  • Right-click chart → 'Add Data Labels' → Show percentages
  • Give your chart a clear title
  • Make sure colours are distinct for each ingredient

For 'Which ingredient makes up the biggest proportion?'

  • Look at your pie chart - which slice is largest?
  • Check the percentages in your data labels
  • Does this match what you expected?

For 'Which ingredient makes up the smallest proportion?'

  • Find the smallest slice in your pie chart
  • This might be a flavouring or raising agent
  • Consider why some ingredients are used in small amounts

For 'Does this surprise you?'

  • Think about what you knew about baking before this activity
  • Are there any ingredients that are larger/smaller portions than expected?
  • Consider the role each ingredient plays in the recipe

If your conversion formulas aren't working:

  • Check that you're referencing the correct cells
  • Make sure you're multiplying, not adding
  • Verify the conversion factor from the table

If your pie chart looks wrong:

  • Ensure you selected both ingredient names AND converted amounts
  • Check that all your conversions are in grams (same unit)
  • Verify no cells are empty or contain text instead of numbers

If percentages don't add up to 100%:

  • This might indicate an error in your conversions
  • Double-check your multiplication formulas
  • Ensure you included all ingredients from your chosen recipe
Self-Assessment Checklist

Before moving on, ensure you have completed:

  • ✅ Selected one recipe from the available options
  • ✅ Created formulas to convert all measurements to grams
  • ✅ Generated a pie chart showing ingredient proportions
  • ✅ Added appropriate chart title and data labels
  • ✅ Answered all reflection questions thoughtfully
  • ✅ Reviewed the 'Did you know?' information about ingredient listing
Submit Your Work

Once you've completed all exercises, your Excel file should contain these sheets:

  • Basic Functions
  • Advanced Functions
  • Charts Practice
  • Inside one cake (completed with your analysis)

Save your file and submit it on Aidan's Central under the FUNCTIONS & CHARTS section.

quiz.question: When creating a pie chart for recipe analysis, why is it important to convert all measurements to the same unit (grams)?
options: To make the numbers look bigger
To ensure accurate proportional representation in the chart
Because Excel only works with grams
To make the calculations more difficult
